name: Рогатик рожковидный - Clavulinopsis corniculata
comment:
Clavulinopsis corniculata, commonly known as the Meadow Coral, is a species of club fungus belonging to the family Clavariaceae. The fruiting bodies of this species are characterized by their slender, unbranched, and often curved, finger-like projections that grow to heights of 3-8 cm.

The surface of the fruiting body is smooth and typically yellow to yellowish-orange in color. As the fungus ages, its tips may become darker.

The spores of Clavulinopsis corniculata are ellipsoid, hyaline, and measure approximately 5.5-8 x 3.5-5 µm in size. The basidia, which produce the spores, are located on the outer surface of the fruiting body.

This saprotrophic fungus feeds on decaying organic matter, particularly plant debris, and plays a vital role in nutrient recycling within its ecosystems.

Clavulinopsis corniculata is commonly found in grasslands, meadows, and other open habitats with well-drained, often sandy or calcareous soils.

The Meadow Coral has a broad distribution, occurring in North America, Europe, and parts of Asia. It typically fruits during the summer and autumn months.

Clavulinopsis corniculata is considered inedible due to its tough, fibrous texture and small size. It is also essential to accurately identify this species to avoid confusion with toxic or inedible mushrooms.

The Meadow Coral is easily confused with other club-shaped fungi, making accurate identification difficult without microscopic examination.

Although there is limited research available on the chemistry and potential pharmacological applications of Clavulinopsis corniculata, other members of the Clavariaceae family have shown promise in this area.

The presence of Clavulinopsis corniculata can be an indicator of healthy grassland habitats, as it thrives in areas with abundant decaying plant material.

As a member of the Clavariaceae family, the Meadow Coral plays a crucial role in breaking down organic matter and recycling nutrients within its ecosystems.
